summary: This document is a chain of emails from January 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff regarding travel approval and logistical arrangements for a team to conduct an interview in Stockholm, Sweden, as part of the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The emails detail flight booking issues, cost concerns, and coordination between legal assistants and prosecutors.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.role: Legal Assistant, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY)
persons.context: She is the primary point of contact for booking travel arrangements (flights and hotels) for the prosecution team traveling for the Epstein investigation. She handles flight changes, cost negotiations, and communicates with the travel agency.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: He is a member of the prosecution team traveling to Stockholm for an interview. He corresponds with Darlene Alleyne about securing refundable flights, expresses frustration over booking errors, and coordinates travel plans with colleagues Alison and Maurene.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: She is a colleague traveling on the same trip to Stockholm. Her flight itinerary is used as a cost benchmark, and Alex attempts to align his schedule with hers to reduce expenses.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: She is a colleague traveling on the same trip to Stockholm. Her flight itinerary is mentioned alongside Alison's as a cheaper alternative.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.role: Supervisory Official (likely at U.S. Attorney's Office)
persons.context: He is the approving authority for travel requests related to the Epstein investigation. He grants approval for multiple trips referenced in the email chain.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: She is copied on several emails regarding travel arrangements, indicating her involvement in the administrative or oversight process.

persons.name: Cynthia Perez
persons.context: She is copied on several emails regarding travel arrangements, indicating her involvement in the administrative process.

persons.name: James Bullock
persons.role: Staff (likely in Budget or Administrative role)
persons.context: Mentioned briefly as someone who was informed about awaiting hotel scheduling, indicating involvement in travel logistics.

connections.description: Alex relies on Darlene to book and manage his travel arrangements for the Epstein investigation. Their communication involves requests, approvals, and some tension over booking errors.
They are colleagues on the same prosecution team traveling together for interviews. Alex adjusts his schedule to match Alison's flights to save costs.
They are colleagues on the same prosecution team, referenced together in travel requests for victim interviews.
Alex submits travel approval requests to Edward Tyrrell, who grants permission for trips related to the Epstein investigation.
Both are staff at the U.S. Attorney's Office; Duncan is copied on travel-related emails, indicating collaborative workflow.
Both are staff at the U.S. Attorney's Office; Perez is copied on travel-related emails, indicating collaborative workflow.

events.title: Travel to Stockholm for Interview
events.description: A team from the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) travels to Stockholm, Sweden, to conduct an interview as part of the Epstein investigation. The trip involves flights from JFK with layovers in Paris.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Interview
events.description: The team traveled to Los Angeles for an interview (or interviews) related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Interview
events.description: The team traveled to Los Angeles for an interview related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel to West Palm Beach for Interview
events.description: Alex and Maurene traveled to West Palm Beach for an interview related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Victim Interview
events.description: The team traveled to Los Angeles for a victim interview related to the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document reveals active investigation travel by the SDNY Epstein prosecution team to Stockholm, Sweden, in early February 2020 for an interview, indicating the international scope of the probe.
The email chain highlights bureaucratic and logistical challenges in booking government travel, including strict requirements for refundable international flights and cost-control measures.
Multiple past trips are referenced (to Los Angeles and West Palm Beach) for victim interviews, showing sustained investigative activity throughout 2019.
The investigation is formally referenced as "United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618, an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity."

The correspondence involves several U.S. Attorney's Office staff (Darlene Alleyne, Michele Duncan, Cynthia Perez) supporting the prosecution team, illustrating the office's resource allocation to the case.
